contextId.information: The phrase "your sight" refers to what Elijah thinks. The captain is pleading with Elijah to let them live. AT: "please consider my life ... as precious to you" or "consider my life ... to be of worth to you and do not kill us" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
contextId.quote: let my life ... be precious in your sight

contextId.information: Here Elijah's spirit refers to his spiritual power. AT: "twice as much of your spiritual power" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: a double portion of your spirit

contextId.information: Here Elijah's "spirit" refers to his spiritual power. This speaks of Elisha having this spiritual power as if it were something that physically rested upon him. AT: "Elisha does have the same spiritual power that Elijah did" or "The spiritual power Elijah had is now with Elisha" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: The spirit of Elijah does rest on Elisha

contextId.information: Here Yahweh's "hand" refers to his "power." AT: "the power of Yahweh came upon Elisha" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: the hand of Yahweh came upon Elisha

contextId.information: Here Yahweh's "sight" refers to what he thinks. AT: "Yahweh considers this as an easy thing to do" or "This is an easy thing for Yahweh to do" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: This is an easy thing in the sight of Yahweh

contextId.information: This refers to the doorway. AT: "the doorway" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: the door

contextId.information: Here Yahweh is referred to by what he said. This phrase is a metonym for Yahweh himself. AT: "Yahweh" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: the word of Yahweh

contextId.information: The king plans to send the men to capture Elisha for him. The king does not plan to capture him himself. AT: "I may send men to capture him" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: I may send men and capture him

contextId.information: This refers to the city where Elisha is. AT: "around the city where Elisha was" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: around Elisha

contextId.information: The king ordered his servants to prepare the food. He did not prepare the food himself. AT: "Then the king ordered his servants to prepare a lot of food for them" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: So the king prepared much food for them

contextId.information: Here the word "kings" represents the armies of these nations. AT: "the armies of the Hittites and the Egyptians" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: the kings of the Hittites and Egyptians

contextId.information: This metonym refers to the amount of money that the harvests of her fields were worth while she was away. AT: "all the profit from the harvests of her fields" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: all the harvests of her fields

contextId.information: Here Yahweh's "sight" refers to what he thinks. AT: "he did things that Yahweh considered to be evil" or "he did things that Yahweh said were evil" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: he did what was evil in Yahweh's sight

contextId.information: Here "Judah" refers to the king of Judah. AT: "the rule of the king of Judah" or "the authority of the king of Judah" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: the rule of Judah

contextId.information: This is another city that was originally part of Judah. Here "Libnah" refers to the people who live there. AT: "the people of Libnah" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: Libnah

contextId.information: Here Yahweh's "sight" represents what he thinks. AT: "he did things that Yahweh considered to be evil" or "he did things that Yahweh said were evil" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: he did what was evil in the sight of Yahweh

contextId.information: Here the prophets' and the servants' "blood" refers to their deaths. AT: "I may avenge the deaths of my servants the prophets and all the servants of Yahweh" or "so that I may punish them for murdering my servants the prophets and all the servants of Yahweh" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: I may avenge the blood of my servants the prophets, and the blood of all the servants of Yahweh

contextId.information: Here the word "blood" refers to "murder" AT: "the murder of Naboth and the murder of his sons" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: the blood of Naboth and the blood of his sons

contextId.information: This means that Jehu sent a messenger to deliver the letters. AT: "Jehu wrote letters and sent a messenger to deliver them in Samaria" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: Jehu wrote letters and sent them to Samaria

contextId.information: Here, sitting on the king's throne means to be appointed as king. AT: "make him king in his father's place" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: set him on his father's throne

contextId.information: Here Jehu's "eyes" refers to his "sight." His "sight" refers to what he thinks. AT: "Do what is good in your sight" or "Do whatever you think is the best" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: Do what is good in your eyes

contextId.information: Here Jehu's "voice" refer to what he says. AT: "to what I say" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: to my voice

contextId.information: Here a person's "heart" refers to their loyality. If a person's loyalty is "with someone," it means that they are loyal to that person. AT: "Will you be loyal to me, as I will be loyal to you? ... 'I will.'"  (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
contextId.quote: Is your heart with me, as my heart is with yours? ... "It is."

contextId.information: Here the mens' "hands" refer to their "control." By being stationed around the temple they were in control of the situation and it was up to them whether people were able to escape or not. AT: "If any of these men that I brought into your control escapes" or "If any of the men that are inside gets away" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: If any of the men whom I bring into your hands escapes

contextId.information: Here "Israel" refers to the people who live there. AT: "the people of Israel sin" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: Israel sin

contextId.information: Here the "heart" represents "desire." AT: "all that I desired for you to do" or "all that I wanted you to do" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: all that was in my heart

contextId.information: Here the "heart" refers to a person's will and desire. AT: "in everything that he did" or "will all of his will" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: with all his heart

contextId.information: Here "in the sight of" refers to Yahweh's opinion. AT: "He did what was evil according to Yahweh" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: He did what was evil in the sight of Yahweh

contextId.information: Here "them" refers to Israel and "hand" refers to the power to control them. AT: "allowed Hazael the king of Aram, and Ben Hadad, his son, to repeatedly defeat the Israelites in battle" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: gave them continually into the hand of Hazael king of Aram and into the hand of Ben Hadad son of Hazael

contextId.information: Here "hand" refers to the power to control them. AT: "he enabled them to be free from Aram's power" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: they escaped from the hand of the Arameans

contextId.information: Here "sat on his throne" refers to ruling as king. At: "Jeroboam became king after him" or "Jeroboam began to rule after him" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: Jeroboam sat on his throne

contextId.information: The phrase "eyes of Yahweh" is a metonym for Yahweh's sight, which is a metaphor for Yahweh's judgment. AT: "what was right in Yahweh's judgment" or "what Yahweh considers to be right" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: what was right in the eyes of Yahweh

contextId.information: Here the word "Israel" represents the people of the kingdom of Israel. AT: "who had caused the people of Israel to sin" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: who had caused Israel to sin

contextId.information: Coming against the land represents coming to attack its people. It can be made explicit that "the land" refers to the land and people of Israel. AT: "came with his army to attack the people of Israel" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
contextId.quote: came against the land

contextId.information: Here the word "Israel" represents the people of the kingdom of Israel. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: he had caused Israel to sin

contextId.information: The phrase "eyes of Yahweh" is a metonym for Yahweh's sight, which is a metaphor for Yahweh's judgment. AT: "what was right in Yahweh's judgment" or "what Yahweh considers to be right" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: what was right in the eyes of Yahweh

contextId.information: "Jotham built" represents Jotham making his workers build it. AT: "Jotham had his workers build the upper gate" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: Jotham built the upper gate

contextId.information: The name "Israel" is metonymy for the people living there. AT: "took the Israelite people to Assyria" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: carried Israel away to Assyria

contextId.information: "Hand" is metonymy for control, authority or power. AT: "the control of" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: the hand of

contextId.information: The location "Judah" is metonymy for the people that live there. AT: "the people of Judah" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: Judah

contextId.information: "Hand" is metonymy for control, power or authority. AT: "handed them over to those who robbed them of their property" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: gave them into the hand of those who would take the possession as spoil

contextId.information: The phrase "raised arm" is metonymy for displaying power and means basically the same thing as "great power." AT: "with very great power" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_doublet]])
contextId.quote: with great power and a raised arm

contextId.information: "This day" is metonymy for the time period in which the writer lived. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: up to this day

contextId.information: "Voice" is metonymy for the message about the command of Yahweh. AT: "the command of Yahweh" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: the voice of Yahweh

contextId.information: "In the ears" is metonymy for being able to listen. AT: "because the people standing on the city wall will hear it and be afraid" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: in the ears of the people who are on the wall

contextId.information: "my power" is metonymy for the ability of the king himself. AT: "from me" or "from the power of my army" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: from my power

contextId.information: "Hand" is metonymy for control, authority and power. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: the hand

contextId.information: "Hand" is metonymy for control, power, or authority. AT: "out from my control" [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: out of my hand

contextId.information: "Fall by the sword" is metonymy for being killed. AT: "I will cause him to die by the sword" or "I will cause some men to kill him with a sword" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: I will cause him to fall by the sword

contextId.information: "House" is metonymy for what was under Hezekiah's control. AT: "Give final instructions to your household and government" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: Set your house in order

contextId.information: To "walk" is metonymy for the conduct of life. AT: "lived my life" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: walked

contextId.information: "Word" is metonymy for the message Yahweh revealed to Isaiah. This is a common way of speaking, an idiom. AT: "Yahweh spoke his word" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
contextId.quote: the word of Yahweh came

contextId.information: "Hand" is metonymy for power, authority and control. AT: "from the control of the king of Assyria" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: from the hand of the king of Assyria

contextId.information: The name is a metonym for the person. AT: "Jerusalem is where I will forever make known who I am." (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: It is in Jerusalem that my name will be forever.

contextId.information: Manasseh probably did not do the work. His servants would have done the work. AT: "that Manasseh had ordered his servants to make" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: that he had made

contextId.information: Here "nations" refers to the people who had lived in the land of Canaan before the Israelites had arrived. AT: "even more than the people whom Yahweh had destroyed as the people of Israel advanced through the land" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: even more than the nations that Yahweh had destroyed before the people of Israel

contextId.information: Here "house" represents family. AT: "the family of Ahab" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: the house of Ahab

contextId.information: The words "shed much innocent blood" are a metonym for killing people violently. It might be best to translate this so the reader understands that other people helped Manasseh do this. AT: "Manasseh ordered his soldiers to kill many innocent people" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: Manasseh shed much innocent blood

contextId.information: Here "eyes" represents Yahweh's thoughts or what he considered about something. AT: "He did what Yahweh considered to be right" or "He did what was right according to Yahweh" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: He did what was right in the eyes of Yahweh

contextId.information: Here "words" represents the message of the law. AT: "had heard the laws that were written in the book" or "had heard the laws that were written in the scroll" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: had heard the words of the law

contextId.information: Here "words" represents the laws. This can be stated in active form. AT: "the laws in this book that Hilkiah has found" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
contextId.quote: the words of this book that has been found

contextId.information: Here "words" represents the message that Huldah just spoke. AT: "About the message that you heard" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: About the words that you heard

contextId.information: Here "heart" represents a person's inner being. Feeling sorry is spoken of as if the heart were tender. AT: "because you felt sorry" or "because you repented" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: because your heart was tender

contextId.information: It might be best to translate so that the reader understands that other people, perhaps Hilkiah and "the priests under him" ([[:en:bible:notes:2ki:23:04|23:4]]), helped Josiah do these things. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: Josiah the king destroyed ... smashed ... threw ... ruined ... broke ... cut down ... filled

contextId.information: "the time when the people of Israel had their own king and the people of Judah had their own king" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: the days of the kings of Israel or Judah

contextId.information: The name is a metonym for the honor that people should give to the person. AT: "People should worship me there" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: My name will be there

contextId.information: Here "mouth" represents Yahweh's command. AT: "as Yahweh had commanded" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: at the mouth of Yahweh

contextId.information: Blood is a metonym for innocent life, and shedding blood is a metonym for killing innocent people. AT: "innocent people whom he killed" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: innocent blood that he shed

contextId.information: Giving a good place at the dining table is a metonym for honoring him. AT: "more honor than the other kings" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: a seat more honorable than that of the other kings
